docs.abstract: Officers were forceful in dispersing demonstrators who stayed out past curfew in the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn.
docs.snippet: Officers were forceful in dispersing demonstrators who stayed out past curfew in the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn.
docs.lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the George Floyd protests in New York City, read Friday’s live coverage.]

headline.main: After Curfew, Protesters Are Again Met With Strong Police Response in New York City

docs.abstract: To participate, submit your response here by June 26 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 7.
docs.snippet: To participate, submit your response here by June 26 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 7.

headline.main: Summer Reading Contest Week 2: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?

docs.abstract: The Golden State is less exceptional and more like the rest of America than many would prefer to believe.
docs.snippet: The Golden State is less exceptional and more like the rest of America than many would prefer to believe.
docs.lead_paragraph: PASADENA — California, the novelist Wallace Stegner wrote, is like the rest of America, only more so. That truism has played out in recent days in scenes of triumph, anguish and incongruity, a mirror of the country seen through a distinctly California lens.

headline.main: The Pandemic and Protests Have Exposed the Truth About California

docs.abstract: The Ford Foundation and four others plan to substantially increase their spending, a splurge financed in part by issuing debt.
docs.snippet: The Ford Foundation and four others plan to substantially increase their spending, a splurge financed in part by issuing debt.
docs.lead_paragraph: The week after the U.S. economy shut down in March, Darren Walker, the president of the Ford Foundation, fielded a stream of phone calls from the heads of dozens of organizations that Ford supports. Many were panicked. One was in tears.

headline.main: Leading Foundations Pledge to Give More, Hoping to Upend Philanthropy
headline.print_headline: Foundations Borrow Heavily To Support a Battered Nation

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: MacArthur, John D and Catherine T, Foundation

byline.original: By James B. Stewart and Nicholas Kulish

docs.abstract: Trump’s tough talk doesn’t seek to address the rage that inequity has bred, but rather to contain it.
docs.snippet: Trump’s tough talk doesn’t seek to address the rage that inequity has bred, but rather to contain it.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, Donald Trump stood in the White House Rose Garden and announced an executive order on police reform — a list of minor, unfunded actions that incentivized some changes but mandated none.

docs.abstract: Brad Luna and Adam Ouanes’s first act as a married couple was to applaud Black Lives Matters protesters walking by the church. It was an act returned by the protesters.
docs.snippet: Brad Luna and Adam Ouanes’s first act as a married couple was to applaud Black Lives Matters protesters walking by the church. It was an act returned by the protesters.
docs.lead_paragraph: A familiar soundtrack of police choppers, emergency sirens and rhythmic chants could be heard outside the Church of St. Luke and the Epiphany on June 6 in Philadelphia, where Brad Luna and Adam Ouanes had just been married by the Rev. Robert Smith, an Episcopal priest.

headline.main: Solidarity in a Wedding and a March
headline.print_headline: In Philadelphia, Two Weddings Amid the Protests

docs.abstract: How liberalism, and the liberal media, are changing before our eyes.
docs.snippet: How liberalism, and the liberal media, are changing before our eyes.
docs.lead_paragraph: Acting editorial page editor Kathleen Kingsbury wrote about the decision to publish our writers’ responses to the Tom Cotton Op-Ed in Friday’s edition of our Opinion Today newsletter.

headline.main: Ross Douthat: The Tom Cotton Op-Ed and the Cultural Revolution

docs.abstract: Talking with two organizers of the movement to reclaim the long-ignored history of Black Wall Street and the Greenwood district’s achievements.
docs.snippet: Talking with two organizers of the movement to reclaim the long-ignored history of Black Wall Street and the Greenwood district’s achievements.
docs.lead_paragraph: The empty storefronts and abandoned buildings that once lined the streets of the Greenwood district in Tulsa, Okla., are becoming canvases for a suppressed history of black excellence.

headline.main: ‘Through Art, I Hope That We Can Make One Tulsa’
headline.print_headline: Applying Creativity To Heal a Wound

docs.abstract: We must get it right this time or risk losing our democracy forever.
docs.snippet: We must get it right this time or risk losing our democracy forever.
docs.lead_paragraph: Our democracy hangs in the balance. This is not an overstatement.

docs.abstract: As the protests against police brutality continue, public officials are warily watching for signs that mass demonstrations are leading to virus outbreaks.
docs.snippet: As the protests against police brutality continue, public officials are warily watching for signs that mass demonstrations are leading to virus outbreaks.
docs.lead_paragraph: None of the plans for how the nation might safely emerge from the coronavirus lockdown involved thousands of Americans standing shoulder to shoulder in the streets of major cities or coughing uncontrollably when the authorities used tear gas to disperse them. No one planned on protesters being herded into crowded prison buses or left in crowded cells.

headline.main: A Delicate Balance: Weighing Protest Against the Risks of the Coronavirus
headline.print_headline: Experts Debate Impact of Contagion at Protests

byline.original: By Amy Harmon and Rick Rojas
